plist.p: Okay, well, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for attending by webcast or in person Glencore's interim results 2012. This morning we have, from the left, Telis, Tor. We have Clinton- Clinton runs our South African operations, if you haven't met him before, Clinton Ephron. Mr. Mahoney I think you met before, the grain business. And obviously Steve and Ivan.
The format will be as usual. Brief presentation on the results, but also looking at ag, the ags business specifically, and South African coal. And then we'll cut to Q&A. Okay? Thank you.
Okay. Morning. So we got our first-half results, and I'll take you through the results, and then the guys will talk about their various divisions and how they performed and going forward.

So the good thing, as you can see the results. We're 24% down, EBIT $2.5 billion which is down 24% on the first half of 2012. But if you look sequentially, on the second half of 2011 to the first half of 2012, which is a good sign, we're 20% up. So annualized for, if you take the first half 2012, they're closely tracking. And you extrapolate that 2011, they're closely tracking the 2011 results.

The marketing business, like we always said at the time of the IPO, is more resilient to the fall of the commodity prices, and I think we displayed that now with the results in the first half of 2012 where the marketing had an EBIT of $1.12 billion, which is 11% down on the first half of 2011, and in fact substantially up if you take the second half of 2011 to the first half of 2012.

Industrial EBIT, like all the other mining companies, is down 32% to $1.4 billion on the first half of 2011, and as expected that's due to the lower commodity prices, average metal prices, which were down during the first half of 2012 to 2011.

Sequentially we have a flat EBIT if you compare it against the second half of 2011, first half 2012, and including associates, it's a flat EBIT. But consolidated EBIT, the first half of 2012, second half 2011 is up 30% due to the strong volume growth which is occurring at our various sites around the world.

Strong cash flow generation with funds from operation $1.9 billion, and adjusted EBITDA interest come in excess of 7%. We have abundant liquidity. We have in excess of $9 billion of committed headroom, and no material refinancing will have to take place in the coming next 12 months.

We have a sector-leading growth pipeline, and if you look at our pipeline of projects, as you know they're brownfield projects; they're not massive greenfield projects with high risks. They're not massive large capital expenditure programs. And these projects are very much on line, on time, and on budget. One or two a little bit behind, but other ones ahead, which we'll talk to in more detail.

Interim dividend of $0.054 per share, which is an increase of 8% over the first half of 2011. So, once again, this reflects the confidence in our commodity diversification, the robustness of our marketing business, the visibility on our brownfield projects, as I said before, which are not high risk, easy ramp-up projects, and once again, we have a strong balance sheet.

So going forward, I spoke about those numbers. There it gives you an idea, where you've got the -looking at the marketing part of the business just once again, which we really try to emphasize to you at the time of the IPO, and I think we've now proved it. The resilience of the marketing business as against falling commodity prices is not linear like you have the assets.

On the asset part of the business, commodity prices fall. It's totally linear. You have profits in that area, whilst the marketing can be robust against commodity price falls. And as you see, we've got 11% drop in our earnings for the first half to first half 2011 to 2012. But if you look at the second half of 2011 to first half 2012, you have around a 70% increase.

Metals and minerals was a good performer. If you look at the breakdown over there, you have an increase in that area, which shows the growth in that area. They increase in the volumes, improved profitability, 9% year-on-year and 13% sequentially. The energy is – if you look first half 2011 to 2012, it's down. But as you can recall, during first half of 2011, you had a lot of arbitrage opportunities; you had the WTI Brent opportunity, which does not exist – did not exist in first half of 2012; and you had a very good performance at 2011. But as you can see, if you compare the energy side of the business, the second half of 2011 to first half of 2012 is a substantial increase.

The ag business has performed well in the first half of the year; and as you will recall, it had a difficult year during 2011, especially during the second half of 2011 due to the cotton losses, and you can see the substantial increase there. We don't have that loss. And the cotton situation is well behind us, and that department is looking – as you know, the commodity price in that area has increased substantially since May this year and is looking very good boding for the future; strong arbitrages, and as we've said with higher commodity prices, tightness in the supply system that bodes well for the company going forward, especially on the marketing side of that business.

Industrial assets, as we said, reduction between the first half to the second half. If you look at metals and minerals, mainly moved on the negative impact of the sovereign and the macroeconomic concerns on metal prices, production performance; but, however, if you look at the second half of 2011, 2012, a slight decrease on adjusted EBIT.

If you look at the ramp-up of the various assets, Mutanda is ahead of schedule, but this has been slightly offset by the delays at Katanga and Kazzinc. But the important feature, we are still online on budget on the costs, with just a slight delay due to the energy situation at Katanga, and Telis can answer any questions later on on that.

Energy substantially on the industrial side is substantially up as you can imagine, because we have the Aseng oil field, which kicked in during 2011, and that was ahead of budget. As you know, that is producing 60,000 barrels of oil a day. We get 24% from that. And on the grassfield (0:03:41) products was mainly just effect on the sugar side of the business.

So I think that gives you an idea of the various assets which we got. I spoke about most of them. If you look at metals and minerals, we spoke about that; energy products, the important issues there. If you look at the energy products, the ramp-up at Prodeco is fully online and on schedule, on budget, once again, on time. These are brownfield expansions, not difficult expansions, with limited risk.

We had additional contribution from our new acquisitions in South Africa from Optimum, Umcebo and our Shanduka transaction, which Clinton would talk about further later on. On the ag production side, as I think you know, we got the new crushing facilities in the Czech Republic and Poland that is coming on stream; and the results were, on the sugar side as I said, little impacted by the sugarcane production during the year.

Looking at our growth projects, looking at compound annual growth; as you'll see, between 2012 to 2015, we have a 18.4% CAGR growth rate. Important feature, if you look at the capital expenditure, you see the growth on our various major operations there. But important feature is whilst the other mining companies have this massive increase in capital expenditures and these big cost outflows, we are reducing considerably.

We are reaching most of the operation with Prodeco will be concluded early next year. Mutanda, Katanga, we are starting – a lot of the money has been spent and it starts reducing. Kazzinc, it has all been spent and now it's just a matter of getting those production schedules up to speed, but very little big capital expansions taking place and very little capital outlays over there. So that's a good sign of the business.

Kazzinc, we – as you know, the gold and silver equivalents is growing and production is ramping up there. We have now, I think, sorted out the situation that was occurring at the Altyntau gold projects, and now that is up to speed; and the copper smelter which is ramping up at Kazzinc is now up to 80% design capacity, so performing fairly well.

On Katanga, that is the one the results were announced recently. The situation at Katanga, we are still on line on budget on capital expenditure. However, we do have delays and Telis can take you through later on in more detail on those delays; and the large amount of the delays and why we didn't have the increase in production that we're expecting during the first half; and for the year, we will be below our budgeted expectation, I think which was announced by the company, so we cannot say much more than what the company announced. But a lot of those delays is due to the power situation in the Congo, and that is a situation which we've worked on and I believe we've resolved. So we will – Katanga will get up to speed and we have now processed with the Phase IV expansion to eventually get Katanga to its design capacity around about 300,000 tons.

Mutanda, the good thing about Mutanda, Mutanda is ahead of schedule and Mutanda will reach its capacity this year of around 100,000 tons production and growing. We are expanding Mutanda and it will hit its annualized ramp-up of 200,000 tons by the end of next year. So just giving you a profile of Mutanda, as I said, we will get there. We are now looking at areas of sulfides (0:07:23) expansion over there at Mutanda. But you can see it has had a 48% expansion during first half 2011 to 2012. And as I said earlier, we will merge Mutanda and Kansuki, and eventually those two projects by the end of 2013 will be annualized at around 200,000 tons.

The goods part on the E&P portfolio in the oil division, as you can see, we had a very successful development of the Aseng field in Equatorial Guinea, which started up in November 2011. And that is, as I said earlier, a 60,000 barrels of oil a day. We get 23% of that, so a very successful operation. The other field in Equatorial Guinea, the Alen field, where we should have production around about 40,000 barrels per day, will be up around quarter-three 2013, we believe, early around about July there and that we will get 24% of the 40,000 barrels a day. So those will be cash generators of income into the company.

We also successfully did our first 100% owned exploration in the Cameroon. That's the Oak-1x Times project. It's been a successful project for Cameroon, and there's a 13.7 meter oil column was discovered in the main prospect with a total net oil pay of 6.2 meters, which has significantly de-risked the adjacent lying areas at similar depths there.

So we will have further appraisals of that during 2013, and we believe this is a substantial field with recoverable oil potentially between 38 and 90 million barrels of recoverable oil, if the adjacent untested structures are included over there. And note very important, this is 100% owned by Glencore.

Prodeco, as I said earlier, moves ahead. We will have the port operating, the new port, in the first half of 2013; once again, on time and on budget. And we are ramping up that Prodeco; as you can see an increase of 12% first half to second half, and by 2013 when the new port is in play, it will be producing around about 19 to 21 million tons of coal.

So then that gives you a full sum up of our various assets, and as I said earlier, the trading – the assets are brownfield expansions; easy, low cost expansions; very little likelihood of cost overruns; on time, on budget, which is lot easier than some of the other mining companies with large greenfield projects. And just – we keep emphasizing, as we said at the IPO, the trading is resilient to falling commodity prices, and I'm pleased to say I think we've proved it during the first half of this year with the resilient trading results even though commodity prices have come off.
So I think with that, I'll let Steve takeover.

Thanks Ivan, and good morning to everyone that's here in the room. Just a few slides on Glencore's financial performance and balance sheet metrics during the course of 2012, the first half. Some of the more detailed operational aspects, Ivan has covered. But maybe at 25,000 feet, you can see some of the comparisons both first half 2012 against first half 2011 as well as the second half 2011 as well.

So you can see some of the sequential developments, and also some of the remarks around where we may end up annualized for 2012 against when we closed the books for the full-year 2011, where we're tracking for full-year 2011. And in a relative terms and a sequential terms that would be a performance year-on-year, as we look forward that would place us in an enviable position within the industrial space.

And that's very much buffeted by the most stable and resilient marketing part of the business and lot of strong growth that we're getting also out of the industrial part of the business; some of which, from both an operating as well as financial perspective, is going to be second half weighted and we'll talk a little bit about that.

So you can see the EBITDA and EBIT variances 17% and 24%. It is a higher variance at the EBIT level, because that's where you get depreciation, we include our share of income from associates comes through that level. But Ivan showed the charts looking at what's the EBITDA split between industrial.

Net income, 26% down at the statutory level contrary to, again, may be many negative movements that's where you often see the differences between underlying earnings and statutory tends to be down. In our case, it's often up through the realizations of value that's been historically going in through historical investments, changes in the investment structures, tax structures that we do as well.

If you look at 2012, we've gone from an underlying $1.8 billion; our statutory return is actually $2.3 billion, which although is not – tends not to be commented too much, only still another facet of the business through value preservation and long-term value that we expect to be going in through the business. There was $466 million, if you look through the details of our financial statements that we've tagged as exceptional to get to the $2.3 billion, which is only a small reduction against first half 2011.

Some of the bigger components in that was a gain on moving our status in the Mutanda investment. Previously, it was an associate where we owned 40%. During May, we did increase a -we bought 20%, moving us to 60%. There's a further option which could potentially move us to 80%. From an accounting classification, that moved us from just equity accounting. So, it's just our proportionate share up to the full consolidation, and the accounting standards does require you to effectively revalue the historical 40% stake up to fair value as it was at May 2012. And there was an accounting gain of $517 million that was booked on the previously held interest in Mutanda.

Also in that line items, you'll see some further tax credits that we've generated what we were able to do as we look towards the potential Xstrata merger. We did some internal structuring around the entities that hold the Xstrata stake within the Glencore Group and it did get moved around and that triggered some gains that will be revenue gains. It will be able to be utilized, particularly in our Swiss tax pays; and it was a tax credit to deferred tax asset, which you will see of $282 million that we book there.

That is real value. That's not a fictitious asset of any sort. It's something that is carried forward we expect to generate Swiss taxable income that allow that asset to be realized in – obviously, in future years. The cumulative effect of the deferred tax asset, in fact that we're carrying on our balance sheet today is well in excess of $1 billion, which is the tax-effected balance, which is going to shelter future tax that may otherwise being payable, which is going to result in stronger FFO and cash generation and an ability to de-lever in the short-term as well.

There were few smaller impairments that we booked; the gross effect was around $100 million. We've commented on the biggest component of that being an impairment we've had against one of the plants in the European biodiesel. It's something that's within our agricultural, a very over-supplied, over-capacity market, tough margins. We had a few plants and we've shut down, we've mothballed one of the plants and that's an impairment against the carrying value there; and some various other smaller pluses and minuses which aggregate to the $466 million as well.

On the – if we look at the balance sheet metrics around equity and debts and the overall shape of the capital structure, our equity base in fact increased $2.5 billion, up 8% from $32.3 billion up to $35 billion. So, there was a slight headline increase also in net debt, which we'll explain in future slides around $1.5 billion. That's been more than compensated by an increase in equity accumulation through transactions that realized value through the profits that we paid, which at least from a balance sheet statics perspective, the gearing ratio if you calculate that. I don't like the balance sheet gearing. It's very much should be cash flow driven. But I know a lot of companies report the balance sheet gearing. We're actually fairly stable at about 28%, 29%, given there is a slight increase in debt, but equally there has been an increase in the equity balance of around $2.5 billion.

If we then move to some of those headline metrics in the balance sheet; Ivan has focused on some of them. We've very much a robust balance sheet, $9 billion of committed liquidity. We've been very active in the different financial markets. The financial statements make reference to those transactions. We've done three or four large bank financings. We've been active in the bond markets in Europe, sterling as well Swiss franc. All of which has resulted us being in a very comfortable position around $9 billion of committed liquidity, and as Ivan said, no material refinancings in the next 12 months.

When you do have a look at our current borrowings, it's essentially made up of some of the shorter term asset-backed structures, the borrowing bases that we do have, the most efficient way of organizing those funding strategies in a 364 day facility. That's backed by a tends to consortium of banks in some cases. Some other investors that tend to be very straightforward to go through an annual renewal process, that's backed by the underlying collateral of oil in tanks, metals in warehouses, receivables to major utilities, to major mining companies et cetera.

And what you really effectively negotiating each year is not the size of the facilities, but what's the pricing for that liquidity, which has its underlying strong collateral value as well. So that's essentially the major things that sit in our current. We do like to keep. And you'll see a slide later on that says even our working capital, which is turning over of 36 days, is backed by two-year average maturity on the funding side of it as well.

Strong cash flow coverage ratios as well. On headline FFO to net debt, you would have seen a drop from 27.2% down to 22.9%. That 22.9% is calculated on the last 12 months and picked up the weaker second half of 2011. So as we roll forward, that I think a better way of looking at pointing and signaling some trend in that is more annualizing first half 2012 against the debt levels and then you back up to the 26.7%, which is effectively a static position of where we were at the end of 2011.

There's still some working capital release to come. We spoke about – six months ago about some build up in working capital, particularly around the end of the year last year, December 2012, we did expect some full release of that working capital. We're still expecting release of working capital to materially arise for the full 2012; around $750 million of that occurred in the first half. We're expecting some further working capital release.

It is something which we've also stressed on numerous occasions; working capital doesn't control you, you control working capital. So for as long as we felt there was a need or it was appropriate to release that working capital, we can do it in a manner of sort of 35 days or so. There is that cycle. But as long as there's good risk-adjusted opportunities, there's plenty of liquidity available for companies like Glencore, we feel, at least from an equity perspective; and certainly managing the credit side of our balance sheet nuts to not seize some of those opportunities that are generating healthy returns in the marketing business on return on equity, whilst still being very mindful1 to manage the balance sheet to make sure that we're delivering on our statements.

S&P and Moody's, certainly investment grade ratings, as we've reiterated are both targeted, and currently BBB watch positive on S&P; Moody's, Baa2, review and direction uncertain. I'm sure you've read their various reports. S&P was quite recent and Moody's the last comprehensive one was more around the March-April time; if you go back, they've given a few updates. So we'll move on, but still very comfortable EBITDA, net interest coverage 8%.

The movement in our net debt $1.5 billion, we're still finalizing some of our historical investment and CapEx profile. But we are peaking in that particular area and should have already peaked now at least in terms of acquisitions. You will have seen the $1.1 billion that we'd purchased in subsidiaries for the first six months. Those were transactions which have been well shadowed for 12 months. That was the finalization of the Optimum transaction, which Clinton will be talking about, moving to control that within various stages.

And also Mutanda moving up to 60%, that's also been something that's foreshadowed the cash flow effects, so those both occurred materially in first half 2012. Property, plant and equipment was also $1.4 billion of CapEx. You annualize that to around $3 billion; again, you're looking at a peak here for us in CapEx. And you saw a slide of Ivan earlier on where we showed the growth in our various main assets going from 12 to 14, but very much a tapering off in CapEx to a sustaining level in two or three years' time.

If we just show this graph, quite a busy profile in terms of credit ratings. What we tried to do is just many in this room would be primarily focused and following the main mining companies, that you'd see in industrials. What we put is a smattering here of both you can see Glencore, which is the hybrid of both the mining industrial side as well as the trading side. So we show the credit profiles of the history of Xstrata, Anglo and Rio on that particular.

We've also got Noble, Cargill and ADM for those that may not have been close enough with them and their historical credit spectrum. Because there is differences in the way that these companies can still have the As or the BBBs while not having exactly the same headline credit metrics. The rating agencies do look at them differently. They do look at marketing aspect and how that's funded. They also look and would allow for certain differences in net debt to EBITDA.

Particularly in Glencore's business and many of the other trading companies, if you go to EBITDA, a normal industrial company needs a stronger ratio there, because it's got high levels of CapEx, generally higher tax rates, which it needs to service from which to pay the debt and be comfortable. We obviously don't have high levels of capital in its traditional sense, its working capital, but it's not capital intensive. The tax rates, of course, in our business are much lower as well. So EBITDA what we do have tends to follow through much quicker through to bottom line and cash flow generation than would be the case for a traditional mining company.

If we look at Viterra, which is one of the big acquisitions that we're looking at now for second half which Chris will talk about, that's also very different to a mining company from a credit perspective. You're buying a utility-like operation that's sitting with the different ports and facilities and grain-handling facilities for which they charge a fee. So they generate that service-like fee. The infrastructure is been built there. It's not particularly complex; technically very low ongoing maintenance. So it's a very different profile to then buying a big mining or an oil operation that you continually need to invest to, to sustain those operations and it's very expensive.

So in the comments on the right hand side, you can see – which I think are important around a business model that has proven to be highly cash flow generative ever since our public ratings across many cycles since 1997. The marketing debt is obviously fundamentally different than the industrial. It's funding short-term, working capital turning over of 36 days and all-in funding costs have less than 5%, which again reflects the different funding markets and underlying collateral for those particular transactions. We've taken an even more conservative angle there, having funded that working capital with on average two-year committed funding facility, which would be more conservative than many others, but of course preserves our own financial strength and liquidity and our targets within the investment grade. So I think it's a useful snapshot.

Similarly, if you look at the next slide, you can see the history of stable credit ratios and just where we are on debt levels today, 2012, first half 2012 against the last five years or so. So you can see debt levels are not – are quite comparable in fact to previous periods. You can see some of the levels we were in 2010, 2012 not too dissimilar notwithstanding the tremendous upgrading and additions that Glencore's made to its asset and earnings base over the years. We are a different company today, first half 2012, than we were with the same debt levels back in 2010.

If you think of all the potential which now exists and that's largely been funded, we've got the oil E&P portfolio; the whole entire African copper base that we have, which has been heavily invested; the South African coal assets; Kazzinc gold; Colombian coal; many ag processing assets. These are all parts of Glencore's earnings stream and asset cover that didn't exist in 2010, yet with still the same debt levels at we are today against those periods.

We're yet to see some of the fruits of many of those investments, which we expect to see. Even that 22.9% FFO to debt, we said annualized that was back to about 27.2%, very strong FFO. And at the time that we do cease to aggressively invest in this business, which we have done in last two or three years, it is a business that could de-lever quite quickly, including the ability to consciously manage the working capital as appropriate. We have invested quite heavily in working capital of course as well.

Just some variances and bridges on the industrial side of our business both sequentially, so this is first half 2012 against second half 2011; in fact on Glencore's consolidated assets, you can see at the EBITDA level, we were in fact up 30% sequentially; and it's more the associate side of our business, which is where we've been flatter period-on-period. But we had $93 million negative variances in price. About half of that was in metals and about half in energy. And on the metal side, nickel and zinc were the two big contributors. On the energy side, coal was lower in price.

Strong volume growth in the sequentially six months, $307 million. The biggest, part about $280 million of that was on the oil – was in energy, and most of that was the oil E&P. There was of course some coal expansion both in Colombia as well as South Africa. On the cost side, there was savings; you can see $28 million positive on savings, that's in nominal terms. In real terms, in fact, it is better because that includes some inflationary elements as well. FX year-on-year – or period-on-period was largely immaterial. Extra depreciation on the back of the volume growth that we spoke about.

The other positive of $83 million, in fact a big component of that really should be in cost benefit, because of the insurance proceeds on PASAR. As you would have read, there was a fire at that plant back in January and was shut down until July. There was a claim for business interruption. It was a fairly straightforward up and down case, for which we've got insurance cover. And the accrual of that, a lot of cash has already been received, is in fact sitting in that which really should be in the cost, because the increase cost would be part of that number.

And the associate income, which includes the Xstrata side, that's where there's some sequential $253 million down to keep a flat structure. The next variance you can see is the period-on-period to the first half of the last year, which is quite a different period – quite a different pricing period; as you can see, $571 million reduction in prices; $475 million of that was in fact metals. We've commented about the metals pricing environment being the main driver of the industrial lower earnings. That's with nickel, you would have seen prices on average down 28%, is higher zinc 15%, copper 14%. So, $475 million, metals affecting those operations. $90 million in energy. Coal, it was a 20% reduction.

On volume growth, $575 million fully covering the drop in prices. Strong volume growth at Kazzinc, which was on the gold side. (0:28:17) as much as nickel is a tough commodity that had a very good operational production performance, record performance in fact in Q2. And on the energy side, volume very strong, there was no oil production on the comparable first half 2011. So there's about $300 million E&P; volume growth in coal was about $115 million (0:28:35).

On the cost side, there is an increase, and again, this is a full nominal cost. So if we strip out inflation, it would be much low. The comparable period was a period still when there was quite intense inflationary pressure. And I would highlight in particular that the mining side was $200 million (0:29:00) of that Kazakhstan over in our Kazzinc operation.

You would similarly have seen some CPIs in Kazakhstan at the ENRCs in Kazakhmys running about 15% at least in that period, but talk about inflation moderating, which we do see as well, but Kazzinc was a big one for that. Peru also a little bit of contribution; we've spoken about some lower grades there. And again, the PASAR insurance is in that $45 million. So really that should be offsetting these. So that provides the industrial bridge.

Just to close on a slide, before we bring Clinton up, we thought we'd put some marketing profitability over the last five years, just to show you some averages where there's a (0:29:37) 2012 appear in the context of history as well. You can see – this is before the corporate little bit of overhead that we had as well.

So just looking at the sector performance, $1.15 billion pre a little bit of overhead, corporate overhead; and in the history where we have split out the segments at least publicly we of course have the data back in our prospectuses in 2008 or 2009. We just gave marketing in aggregate terms, we didn't break it up into those segments. And you can see the sort of run rates and which are good years and which are poor years.

I think when we have been on sort of road shows and the like, we've tried to pitch the marketing business in a EBIT of sort of $2 billion to $3 billion type range when market conditions are more vibrant and more arbitrage opportunities, inventories tighter. You would tend to be on an annualized basis close to the $3 billion. When markets are poorer, you tend to be around the $2 billion level.

So we are at around the $2.2 billion, $2.3 billion annualized, which would be starting to get into the mid-range. And the averages that we achieved in the first half across metals, energy and agri not too dissimilar to what we've achieved in the four, five years before that. So I think a good bit of history there and trying to think about what the future may hold there.

So with that, we have done a lot on South African coal in the last 12, 15 months. We've brought Clinton up from Johannesburg. I think it's an area which is from a modeling and an understanding is quite narrow. So, we'll try and see if we can upgrade all that.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. A quick run-down of South African coal; it's one of the newest areas in Glencore, one of the newest growth areas in Glencore, which we've been building up for the last few years. Basically, the next few slides from our perspective is just to try and give you a run-down of our vision of South Africa, what we've been doing for the last few years down there and to give you some sort of perspective of what we see for the future.

So back in 2005, we teamed up with a prominent businessman, previously politician Cyril Ramaphosa to create a Black Economic Empowerment Company, where previously Glencore owned 70%; we owned – Shanduka owned 30%, which is Cyril's company. And we decided we're going to try and as best we could consolidate some of the industry in South Africa, where there were still some reasonable sized independent coal companies.

And we set out on a task and we initially bought Shanduka Coal back in – we created Shanduka Coal, which bought a number of smaller collieries back in 2005. That company produces approximately 6 million tons of coal at the moment. And then over the years, we've managed to, let's say, opportunistically build up this company to today which is approximately 27 million tons, as you can see I've got little pointer over there.

So we started off with Shanduka Coal back in 2005. By 2009, we started negotiating with a company called Umcebo Mining and we subsequently bought into that company, which gave us 43%. Cyril Ramaphosa also owns approximately 35% of company Shanduka and there's one other outside shareholder in that company. And we've split it up into two segments part of this – part of our South African coal assets being the Glencore controlled assets and being the non- Glencore controlled assets, where we have a large minority stake in this (0:33:19) and I'll talk about it now.

So let's start at the top. Optimum Coal, which is our recent acquisition, you may have obviously read quite a lot about it. It's a – it was the fourth largest exporter in the country. We set about acquiring this asset in 2011, and through a complex mechanism of various structures, it allowed us to make inroads into this company, buying out a lot of the BEE companies together with Cyril Ramaphosa's company.

And we managed to obtain a substantial amount of this company before the market even realized that we had actually bought into the company. Ultimately, it's now resulted in us as Glencore earning an effective 64% of this company. This company produces 14.2 million tons. 6.8 million tons this year we will export, and as you can see over there, 7.4 million tons we've sold into the domestic market.
